caption: Here's another oasis in the middle of Paris that brings freshness and joy to the day! Most visitors here know the magic of slowing down and absorbing the wonder of the sights, smells, and feel the plants, air, and water have to offer. Come away recharged from this beautiful place!

A great place to escape the city and relax on a hillside. Bring a book amd a blanket.  On Sundays you'll find families and lots of children playing.  Drinks are available at a couple locations in the park.  Public restrooms are also available.  Walking the entire loop takes less than an hour.  It is quite Hilly in places so you may need to take breaks at one of the many park benches.
I adore this place so so so much. It's stunning. Huge too, so there's lots to explore. A well-needed respite from the hustle and bustle of Paris. A must-visit.
Beautiful park just a little out of the way of the busy citycentre. Which is a good thing; locals stolling through the park or jogging along and just having a relaxed good time.
What a wonderful place: a green oasis of tranquility in the middle of Paris. Not the typical cultivated parc, but a more natural environment. Nice place to relax or enjoy a picnic.
Beautiful parc to escape from busy life. Also peaceful and relaxing when you need to be alone on your own

Me and my friend walked to this park after our rave at kilometre 25 around 6:30AM on a Sunday. We were both ecstatic after the rave and when I first layed my eyes onto the pavilion over the lake, it felt so divine to me. I proposed to lay on the lawn as nobody was there but it just rained and my friend thought it would be a bad idea to get wet hence we had a very nice walk in the park instead. I didnâ€™t take this photo as I wasnâ€™t in the mood of taking photos when in the park but the divine view was similar to this shot I found on the web.

Beautiful park in a pleasant area. During our visit, much of the park was not open. We couldnâ€™t go onto any of the bridges or get up to the temple like viewing point due to renovations. If you are visiting in 2024 I would bear this in mind :)

Gorgeous park, the lake is under construction until 2024. I bet it will be more beautiful afterwards. Peaceful, tons of old growth trees and benches. Great for walking, jogging, picnic, or just sitting and relaxing. Almost like a mini version of Central Park in New York (without the cops.. ðŸ˜…). â€¦

One of best parks I've seen in Paris. A lot of nature, wild looking parts, lake, small creeks, hills, places to stay in the sun, to drink a glass of wine, a couple of restaurants and bars. Very nice for children, couples... Beautiful!
One of the excellent parks in paris! Diverse areas with different styles and nature, very spacious, very very busy on sunny days but such a good vibe!
Huge and lovely park, a slice of peace in the bustle of Paris

Fairly boring hilly park. The views arenâ€™t that special as they are in the wrong direction so all you see are housing estates. Lots of construction work and the lake has been drained with the temple closed, so unless you want a challenging place to run, Iâ€™d say avoid it.

Parc des Buttes-Chaumont, located in northeastern Paris, is one of the cityâ€™s most distinctive and picturesque parks. Covering over 61 acres, it offers a refreshing contrast to the more formal and structured gardens typical of Paris, such as the Jardin des Tuileries or Luxembourg Gardens. Opened in 1867 under Napoleon III, the park is known for its dramatic landscape, featuring steep cliffs, winding paths, waterfalls, and a man-made lake.  One of the parkâ€™s most iconic features is the Temple de la Sibylle, perched atop a cliff on the ÃŽle de la BelvÃ©dÃ¨re, offering panoramic views of Paris, including a stunning perspective of Montmartre. The parkâ€™s elevation changes provide a unique topography, with caves, grottos, and bridges that add a sense of adventure to every walk. Its design, inspired by the Romantic English gardens, creates an atmosphere of wild beauty, enhanced by the parkâ€™s carefully curated but naturalistic landscaping.  Parc des Buttes-Chaumont is a haven for locals and tourists alike, providing ample spaces for picnics, relaxation, and outdoor activities. The park is particularly popular with families and joggers, offering several playgrounds and scenic trails. Its diversity of flora, alongside occasional art installations and cafÃ©s, makes it a dynamic and vibrant space to explore. Overall, it is a serene yet lively retreat from the urban hustle, providing a perfect blend of nature, history, and recreation.
Nice park with some gradient tracks for running uphill and downhill.

I adore this park. The nature is incredible â€” the trees, the water fall, the trails. There are a fair amount of people but it does not feel crowded. Plenty of space to sit and relax, read, eat, etc.

A hidden green gem in the middle of the city. The 150 year old park is ancient, and is gearing up for renewal/restoration. Regardless owing to its popularity the place was packed to brim by runners, casual walkers, picknicking families and alike. Lovely place.

Parc des Buttes-Chaumont in Paris is a beautiful escape from the city's bustle. With its scenic lake, cliffs, and lush greenery, it's perfect for a peaceful stroll or picnic. The park's unique layout, charming bridges, and stunning views over Paris make it a must-visit spot.

Nice large park with several benches to rest and shaded areas.  Open 24 hours a day and often busy.  Most people are running or walking the paths.  There are several spots that have nice views of parts of the city.  Small lake with a couple small bridges.  I did not see any dogs while strolling the park so not sure if they are allowed.  Nice for an afternoon stroll but probably not worth going out of your way to visit.

Nice little park to spend time outside, do some running or walk your dog. In the middle there is a lake with a small island. At the moment it can't be accessed due safety matters. You will also a mini cave next to the lake. Plenty of benches to seat around, a small playground for children. The park offers view points over the surrounding area. Toilet facilities available in the park. Inside you will find a restaurant with a nice over the lake. Closest metro stations Buttes Chaumont and Botzaris. Few bus stops around the park.

A big, undulating park with lots of fascinating features. Unfortunately the high rise footpath bridge was closed due to repairs when we went, but loads of places to sit and relax and lots of little adventures to be had for kids roaming the park on their own too.

I visited the park recently and had a wonderful experience! The park was clean, well-maintained, and had a great atmosphere. There were plenty of trees and green spaces, making it perfect for a peaceful walk or picnic. The playground equipment was in good condition and my kids had a blast. The park also had clean restrooms and ample parking. Overall, I highly recommend this park for anyone looking for a relaxing outdoor getaway.

Quite a big and beautiful park, clean and easy to get here. There are also several nice spots that you can see some parts of Paris from these hills. You can also see planes approaching in/out to the airport (in a bit far distance but still nice to see).  Very good place for walking, running or just chilling outside with nature is so beautiful.

Parc des Buttes-Chaumont is a breathtaking green haven in the heart of Paris, perfect for a summer visit. Its scenic beauty, with waterfalls, a serene lake, and the iconic Temple de la Sybille, offers a tranquil escape from the city's bustle. The park is vibrant and lively, especially with young Parisians enjoying picnics and gatherings, though it's equally welcoming for all age groups. Whether you're looking to relax, stroll, or admire the stunning views, this park is a must-see destination.

I would love to give this spot a five and I am sure if I went when things were accessible I would have. My husband and I visited in July. We got some croissants and pastries, some lemonades and had our Kindles. I had always wanted to visit here but upon arrival we found that the hill and bridge were inaccessible. This was upsetting. The other thing that kind of ruined the day was lack of toilets. I have never gone to a large park and had no bathrooms. There were portajohns without toilet paper and absolutely unwelcoming so we had to leave to go find washrooms before starting our peaceful stay. We sat by the water on one of the benches under a large tree. It was the epitome of peaceful until ... it seemed every school in that district had a field trip occur. I actually loved seeing the children play - it reminded me of when I taught in England but just a head's up if you go on a weekday it may not be quiet. The park was clean and well maintained. Hopefully I can visit again in the future when the bridge is accessible. Was a really nice park.
Lovely. A lot of happy people and dogs of all ages.  We had a lovely picnic while we watched everyone go by.
One of the prettiest parks in Paris.

Built by Napolean III the park is still loved and used by the locals and visitors to Paris. Nothing too fancy about it though, Has a small childrenâ€™s area to play (children 8-10 yrs and below as it is a constrained space.  There is visible history here, but not too much of it. Good for a one time visit.

This is a wonderful park that has everything you could need from a park: beautiful green grass, old trees, a lake, multiple levels of interest, a waterfall, free water fountains, a cafe that sells amazing ice creams and sorbets as well as a fabulous monument on top of a cliff in the centre of the lake. The view from the top of the monument is fantastic.  Some people have complained about it being too crowded but it wasn't crowded at all when we went. It was a Monday rather than a weekend and  it was really hot and sunny but we easily found a space to eat a picnic.  and weren't bothered by crowds at all. Possibly this was because it was August so all the Parisians were away on holiday but probably also because it is slightly off the beaten tourist track (we seemed to be the only Brits there).  I can't recommend this beautiful park highly enough!

If you want to see more green spaces in Paris, I suggest to visit the hilly and big Park des Buttes-Chaumont (Metro station: Buttes-Chaumont). Parc des Buttes Chaumont is the fifth largest park in Paris. Have the time, comfortable shoes and patience to get there and see at least a part of this beauty spread over 25 hectares. Of course, we wanted to see and walk along the suspension bridge created by Gustav Eiffel (yes, the very one of the Eiffel Tower) but it was under reconstruction. Which means even the famous Temple de la Sybille is a Roman-style monument situated at the highest point of the park, perched some 165 feet above the lake with its Belvedere observation deck is now closed. It's very smart to take some food with you as it's a great place for a picnic with lots of benches. There is a restaurant in the park. Despite everything, we really enjoyed visiting this historical park.

Worth checking out if you have some extra time as it is outside the touristic area, in 19th arrondissement. I came here to meet some Parisian friends and we had such a great time, I forgot to get to the top view point at Temple Sybille, before the gate closed (it was closed by 6:45pm when I went). The park is huge and hilly and can great crowded on sunny days - though there is always space for one more ðŸ˜€.

Parc des Buttes-Chaumont is an exquisite gem nestled within the heart of Paris, captivating visitors with its unparalleled beauty and serene ambiance. With its lush, rolling landscapes, artfully crafted gardens, and stunning vistas, the park offers a perfect escape from the bustling urban life.  The centerpiece of the park, a picturesque lake with a charming island crowned by a rustic temple, creates a scene reminiscent of a romantic painting. Meandering paths wind through enchanting groves and towering trees, inviting leisurely strolls and peaceful picnics. The carefully designed landscape seamlessly combines nature and architecture, showcasing a harmonious blend of serenity and elegance.  One cannot help but be enamored by the diverse plant life, vibrant flowers, and tranquil water features that grace every corner of the park. Its elevation changes and rocky terrain offer unique viewpoints of Paris, making it a photographer's paradise. As the seasons change, the park transforms, casting a different spell with each passing month.  Parc des Buttes-Chaumont is not just a park; it's a symphony of nature's best elements orchestrated to provide a respite for the soul. Whether you're seeking a romantic rendezvous, a peaceful retreat, or a place to connect with nature, this park transcends expectations and paints an unforgettable portrait of tranquility in the heart of a bustling city.

To the northeast of the city center, in the 19th, sits this 60-acre beautiful park. Great trails and paved paths for a hike or run while surrounding stunning green spaces, waterfall, and a pond make for a soothing escape. Nice restaurant and cafe onsite. Overall it's a wonderful place to spend time when you want to get out of the city and connect with some quiet nature.

It's one of the prettiest parks I've ever seen, really beautiful with the hill and the temple and the bridge up high over the water. Unfortunately, the temple of Sybil is a little sketchy. The gates are falling apart and there's graffiti everywhere, which is sad to see. Otherwise it's a lovely spot.
Beautiful park but the best part, the island, is not accessible (August 2024)

A really nice park. Sadly, some parts are not accessible at the moment (the bridges and hilltop) due to construction work. As everything was written in French we couldn't understand why. Hopefully, it will be accessible again in the future.

Donâ€™t sleep on the gelato stand in the center of the park, it is top tier. The park is filled with what seem to be historical landmarks, and beautiful views of the city. Some stairs or inclines are quite intense, but this is the gem in the middle of a lovely area!
Absolutely gorgeous. I could have stayed here all day. There's plenty of green space to have a picnic, lay in the sun, people watch or just enjoy the scenery.
